comments.commentBody:
I doubt that public officials truly buy the concept that American troops need to be in so many places throuhgout the world or that American forces are necessary to police so many different regions. In reality, I believe decisions pertaining to military expenditures are to a large degree business decisions, and the politicians who support these expenditures do so largely for business reasons, whether for military bases and/or vendors in their districts or perhaps for campaign contributions from the many varied military contractors. Further, while many politicians might resist any effort to curtail military expenditures, the fact should not be lost that the military, while having a peacekeeping component, is a killing machine. Why not spend some of the savings from a less boated military on more fruitful endeavors.
Finally, we need more independent analyses than what the military provides as to the required size of our presence abroad, the myriad weapons systems available now or in the works, and for the sheer number of troops. It's a clear conflict of interest for the military to be the source of much of this information. Instead, we need an independent mechanism to consider threats the military itselt asserts so that a more independent evaluation of such threats and their appropriate responses may be reached.

The defense budget is essential to ptrotecting all americans. We should cut programs that only benefit a minority of americans such as medicaid and medicare, food stamps and welfare. These programs are no longer affordable and cutting them would not undermine national security.

I find it comical how liberals led by Paul Krugman argue religiously to increase the size of government expenditures due to their stimulative nature, while at the same time religiously arguing for the downsizing of the military budget.  Where do you think all the money for soldier pay, health benefits, contracts for suppliers goes?  Into the US economy!

any social programs run by the government are usually a mess...full of bureacracy, red tape, and low-paid, uneducated workers.  Is anybody surprised by these kind of results?  It's the same as the foster care system.

A terrific, if deeply troubling story; thank to DANNY HAKIM and RUSS BUETTNER and the NYTimes for supporting such investigations.

Now I wonder how Mississippi will handle all of its single celled "persons" compared to its already existing, fully embodied, but disabled, disoriented and otherwise disturbed citizens.

Yes, the human beings generally do care, but we have created a division of labor so that we need not pay attention to whether others get care. This is a social pathology to be unconscious of all of our interconnections.

Again, thanks to the NYTimes and DANNY HAKIM and RUSS BUETTNER for taking some of us out of our stupor.

Why don't we just call this what it really is, murder!  Why doesn't the Justice Department investigate these murders?  Who are the people who own and/or run these facilities?  We pay for the care and well-being of patients through our taxes, so we have a right to demand answers.  We also have a right not to be murdered by "caretakers" should we become incapacitated.

Some of the comments are appalling...the DNR types especially.  What it demonstrates is a culture which has lost it's soul, looking only at the bottom line.  And the fault is widespread...real estate agents and bankers who benefit from high fees for housing sold to non-profits which provide care for people with DD; the tea party types from whom all of life is restricted to no new taxes; the CEO's of non-profits who make far too much money; the exploited care-givers in homes; the absence of any enforceable standards as well as the willingness of "no government" people to decry any kind of regulation; states which demand high standards but offer no financial assistance to help struggling non-profits pay for them;

California's dysfunctional program burned 6 individuals today; 4 are already dead.
The arrogance is staggering; the "system" punishes any parent who is pro-active concerning their children.

New York State Assembly member Andrew J Stein stood up for the children of the Willowbrook State School. He exposed outrageous abuses.
His subsequent life path notwithstanding, he did very good work.

You readers who wonder how this could happen might want to go look upstate a bit at the Poughkeepsie Journal, who did a tremendous series on how the state government uses Medicaid accounting gimmicks to divert hundreds of millions of dollars a year, away from state facilities for the developmentally disabled.

Where the money went from there, maybe somebody would like to ask the state legislature.

Here's where you start: http://www.poughkeepsiejournal.com/article/20100716/NEWS01/7160343/Feds-...

The Journal also did more recent follow-ups, if you care to chase them down.

In those pieces it was insisted that the disabled were still getting top-notch care - and for what we've been spending, they sure should have.

Now with this information from the Times we found that not even -that- was true.

Once again, our state managed to spend more than anybody else AND have worse outcomes than anybody else.

There's a message in there someplace, but it probably bounced off the state legislature's Cone of Incompetence.

"I believe that God put these people here for a purpose, because if we didn't have them to look after, we would lose our humanity."

I felt greived when I read above quote by you in NYT.
As a Muslim I believe none dies before the last of the provision
is consumed and without reaching the preserved time, we have no knowledge of.

Why did Mr Taylor's family get rid of him? Certainly with 5 able-bodied adult siblings they could have cared for him at home. Just don't understand this culture where people refuse to take care of elderly or disabled family members.  Mr Taylor's family and the other families of disabled or elderly in "care facilities" are just as blameworthy as the staff who work there.  Why can't five people care for one brother?  Why can't a group of siblings care for one elderly parent?

This is the first investigative reporting I've seen in the New York Times after two years of subscribing to it online...and it's excellent! We have been battling a similar crisis here in Oklahoma with child welfare. Too many children have died of physical abuse and murder, when placed with dangerous caretakers, by a state agency usurping the common sense of the families involved.

There has been a shakeup of this agency now that people have brought knowledge of the incredible death rate involved to light. I hope that your research will stir the state of New York to further protect the helpless: children, animals, the elderly and ill, as well as the developmentally disabled.

Continue to stir that pot, please! Investigative reporting is the only way most of us learn about, and can act upon, these horrible situations!

Its alarming to read all the comments here that fail to even see the whole picture. Each and everyone of these deaths is heart felt by the agencies and the staff that work with them. We are NOT treating people as disposable. We do not lack regulation and oversight, training and a sense of duty and responsibility.We are not staffed by people who are so unskilled they just cannot work anywhere else as some have said. Decades in this field have shown me the care and love and attention given by so many and in so many ways. Staff reaching out in their own time to help improve the quality of life of those they support. While there has to eb aplace for journalism that uncovers wrongs and while there is no defence for abuse of those who are most vulnerable ever, the articles in the Times continually seem to seek to depict our field as manned by uneducated, insenstive, money grubbing abusers. It is just not the case. There is accountability.When a relative states that the sad death of a family member saw the person who directly neglected them being made "the scapegoat" while others were not held accountable, we see a major issue: it was the responsibility of the person who left that individual. It was their action, their inexcusable lack of responsibility to duty that resulted in that terrible event. I know that agency. I know the training that is in place and the oversight and the good work that is done. I know the house it happened in. All of these incidents are terrible. Abuse cannot and should not ever be tolerated. But Mr Hakim and the people that so freely comment in these comment sections also need to employ a more balanced point of view. Where is the objective journalism? I am saddened by this continuing depiction of this profession (and it is a PROFESSION) as an unregulated, wild-west like situation. We are so very aware of the need to improve. But WE are also aware of the good, the amazing, the enlightened and the loving work that is done by so many, every day.
These poor creatures should all be with their families!!!

With this type of abuse occurring in nursing/group homes, it is troubling that the USDOJ chose to advance the case of the so-called whistle-blower Dr. Gabriel Feldman.  Assuming that he was correct, and the bureaucratic process of obtaining homecare was not entirely complied with, the options advanced by Dr. Feldman, namely institutionalization or a reduced level of care is draconian.  I hope the USDOJ is proud!

While it is true that these deaths should not have happened it is important to keep them in perspective. The OPWDD system is responsible for over 126,000 individuals. Most of these deaths appear to be caused by human error which is unavoidable no matter how many regualtions are put in place.
The vast majority of the individuals in the OPWDD system have had their lives enhanced through the services provided by NYS and its nonprofit partners. At some point the Times should present a balanced view of the system and show some of the good work performed by the many nonprofit agencies and state employees. Based on the Articles in the Times it is clear that they are determined to use a small sample to tarnish the entire system.

Many readers feel that they must condemn parents for placing their children in group homes; surely everything would be fine if those parents and other family members cared for these residents in their homes.

But that is unrealistic for most families. Joan Taylor was 80 years old when James died; should we assume that she and her husband had the strength and skills needed to help a quadriplegic adult? In the next generation, that of James and his siblings, both members of most couples have to work in order to maintain the family. It's not affordable for one spouse to stay at home, but many severely disabled people, like those in these state homes, need round-the-clock care.

I know of at least one home for developmentally disabled people in my own area that was founded over 50 years ago by aging parents who worried about where their children would live after they, the parents, died. Many of them had only one child, so they couldn't expect brothers and sisters to take care of the disabled sibling.

My sister cares for developmentally disabled adults through a nonprofit in Pennsylvania. While there are obvious differences between the system she works in and the one described in this story, the agency she works for expect superhuman feats of their staff. There are times they work 18 hour days and then need to be back to work less than six hours later. They have hours of uncompensated time doing reams of paperwork (yet are not allowed to read any of their colleagues' notes when they are assigned to a new case or even sent to sub). They are tasked with driving aggressive patients who have required car restraints in the past in their own vehicles with no restraints other than a seatbelt, and as a result, are bitten, have their hair pulled out, and one colleague even had her arm broken by a patient's aggressive behavior. All this for an hourly wage much lower than many basic administrative positions in other fields.

This is a system that desperately needs universal minimum quality of living standards, for both the patients and the staff directly working with them. What is not needed is to blame the staff, who are burnt at both ends and often (though not always) very well-intentioned, hard-working, and just trying to do the best possible job in a very stressful, under-resourced situation.

It is interesting that the only reason for a government is to protect it's citizens. If the government wants out of the protection business, then why do we need a government?

If Americans just want want to be fed, a free roof over their head, free health care, and a week weekly allowance (otherwise known as SS, welfare, or unemployment); then, why don't Americans just create a cost saving United States of Charity, and eliminate the waste, overspending, and bureaucracy of something called a governmental charity organization.

A thoughtful appeal for U.S. military intervention against Iran.
Now that Israel has introduced nuclear weapons into the Middle East, is there still hope for an agreement creating a nuclear-free Middle East?
What is the Israeli position on this possibility?

Some thoughts:

1. How is a nuclear Iran's threat to Israel different than was a nuclear Nazi Germany's threat to the Allies?

2. Why is Israel exempt from the national fear of an “existential threat" when the nation behind the perceived threat has made it clear on many occasions that it views Israel as an abomination subject to removal?

3. Other than its Arab neighbors, who are Iran's real enemies? Israel is not an historic threat. And, it needs mentioning, who funds Hezbollah, Hamas, etc. and why?

4. Why is Israel's nuclear capability any less sacrosanct or any more threatening than that of the US? After all, as we are constantly reminded, the US was founded on Judeo-Christian ideals.

I offer that that those who fear the Israeli nuclear threat are projecting their own thoughts, philosophies and fears on Israel.

We don't have to fight wars and sacrifice American lives and trillions of dollars we do not have just because Israel wants us to. We did not need to do that in Iraq and we don't need to do that in Iran. Both countries could be a threat to Israel, but they were never a threat to America. Will Americans ever learn that Israel is a foreign country and they are not our colonial masters.

This comment is addressed to readers who are not so blinded by their hate of Israel as to accuse it of "occupying several Arab countries", "genocide", "making America fight its wars" and other such fancifuly heinous crimes.
Iran does not have to use nuclear weapons. It only needs to show that it can, and then bully the Sunni Arab states in the ME into Allah knows what kind of submission.
But in addition, Iran can be irrational - all they need is a little fatwa, from a big Ayatollah. Religion, in particular a messianic one, can easily breed irrationality.
Finally, Israel has (rightfully, IMO) the "never again" complex. Thus, it bombed Iraq's nuclear reactor into the dust, it destroyed Syria's N.Korean built reactor, it may yet feel deserted to its fate by the world (as it was in 1967) and thus believe it must alone stop an Iranian bomb. This last scenario is not inconcieveable.

It's a very poor idea for us to have such bad relations with Iran.

I have always thought that we missed a huge opportunity with September 11th. We should have used our moment of good will to try to achieve some detente with Iran. We could have easily found common cause, since the alliance of Al Qaeda and the Taliban posed problems for the Iranians as well (drug trafficking, discrimination against Afghani Shiites). With other nations to help put pressure on the Taliban leadership, we could have forced them to hand over ben Laden and not wasted 10 years, trillions of dollars, and thousands of lives.

I'm not interested in starting a war with Iran, and especially not over nuclear weapons. While they might be building them, they are rational actors and are using them for deterrence, not seriously planning an attack. And why do they feel a need for deterrence? Who are Iran's enemies: Saudi Arabia and Israel. Both are a threat to Iran in part because of the support they get from us. So, would it be better to start yet another war, with serious spillover consequences, or just to ease up and disengage with both of these false-friend allies? And if our choice is one that doesn't seem to make sense, we should ask ourselves just whose interests our government is serving; the American people's or their own?
